text: It's finally happened.  Hell's frozen over. Christmas is two weeks off, arid SNOW is falling in Gotha Beneath its pristine white blanket, the city looks uncharacteristically serene -- almost  inviting .  Peace has been miraculously restored: strangers wave hello.  Salvat Army Santas ring their bells on streetcorners.  And now, night falls, an ILLUMINATED SIGN winks on above Broad Ave "JOYEUX NOEL GOTHAM -- Only 16 Shopping Days Left Till Christmas." The streets are bustling with jolly shoppers.  At a souve store, we find an exasperated MOM squabbling with her sev year old.  Like many other storefronts in Gotham, this on overflowing with bootleg BATMAN MERCHANDISE: t-shirts, ke chains, ceramic figurines.  The kid is already wearing a Batman baseball cap and a little black cape, but he obvio wants more. Mom drags him off past another store window, this one ful SCRAP METAL, with a sign reading "AUTHENTIC FRAGMENTS OF BATWING -- $19.95 and up."  A PANHANDLER is perched at th entrance.  Beneath his array jacket is a grubby sweatshir with the familiar yellow-and-black logo.  In Gotham this winter, Batmania is everywhere...

Two hours later, the SNOWSTORM's grown into a full-fledge blizzard.  The drifts are two feet deep and the streets a all but empty of cars.  A massive SNOW PLOW the size of a Panzer tank rumbles past, FILLING THE FRAME... ...and revealing, as it passes, a group of CAROLERS, all bundled up in mufflers and parkas.  Unbothered by the wea they walk the street singing, spreading cheer and goodwil the few passersby. They've just gone into a lovely  a capella rendition of "Silent Night" when an oversized DELIVERY TRUCK, outfitted with s chains, clanks slowly past in the wake of the plow.  Its are decorated with cartoon igloos advertising a popular i cream snack -- POLAR BARS -- oddly inappropriate for this of year. A streetcorner SANTA, with bell and bucket, WAVES at the as it rounds a corner.  The CAROLERS carol.  Then -- -- a VIOLENT EXPLOSION rocks the street -- followed by th sound of AUTOMATIC GUNFIRE and a high, wailing SECURITY A

Around the corner there's CARNAGE on the streets.  The wi have blown out of Gotham's leading jewelry store.  Gut-sh SECURITY GUARDS stagger and go face down in the snow as ROBBERS, dressed in white camouflage gear, clamber out th the shattered glass with SACKFULS OF LOOT. CAROLERS spill around the corner to see what's going on, spray of GUNFIRE sends them scattering in panic.  The POL BAR truck pulls even with the jewelry store, and as it do The REAR DOORS open.  A RAMP slides down from the back of truck.  The ROBBERS scramble aboard, and mere seconds lat SLIDE out AGAIN -- riding atop five SKIDOO SNOWMOBILES. SIRENS HOWL.  A POLICE CAR appears, taking the corner jus trifle too fast -- FISHTAILING on the icy street and plow into a drift.

The COPS gun the engine, but their wheels are spinning in snow -- no traction.  They're about to climb out and give chase on foot when, through the windshield, they see the Salvation Army SANTA... ...HOISTING AN AK-47 AND FIRING DIRECTLY AT THEM.  The windshield disintegrates and the COPS sink from view as S races off to the last of the snowmobiles, which is alread burdened with LOOT.

MORE SQUAD CARS converge on the jewelry store -- but it's difficult to carry on a high-speed pursuit when the snow' foot deep and the best you can do is 6 MPH.  The COP CARS to a halt, blocked by the rumbling SNOWPLOW.  By now, of course, the LOOTERS are gone -- scooting off on either si the plow, sticking to the snowy sidewalks.

SNOWMOBILES glide across the sidewalks, sending the few h souls who are out on the streets DIVING FOR COVER.  A cou of DERELICTS are cowering behind a fire hydrant, trying t avoid getting run over.  Every time they poke their heads another SKIDOO whizzes past, missing them by inches. The ROBBERS fan out in various directions.  These guys ar obviously going to get away clean --  unless ... The DERELICT points up at the night sky, where a BEACON i blazing in the darkness -- THE BLACK SILHOUETTE OF A BAT.

MORE SIRENS.  A COP takes a radio call as he streaks down long wide avenue which borders Gotham Park -- one of the streets which is relatively clear.  The COP at the wheel wide-eyed and nudges his partner in disbelief. Before their eyes, FIVE SNOWMOBILES appear from the cross streets up ahead and CONVERGE at the entrance to Gotham P Bringing up the rear is SANTA CLAUS.
What the hell -- ?

Several squad cars are now massed at the entrance to the park -- but there's one problem.  The cit snow plows don't operate on the park roads -- and the ent is blocked off with SAWHORSES reading "CLOSED TO TRAFFIC. huge steep drift prevents them from entering -- and so al they can do is stand by helplessly, WATCHING as the snowmobiles vanish into the trees. The COPS race about like headless chickens, trying to con a plan.  A couple of them are trying to scale the stone w of the park.  Another is at his car, barking into a radio mike:

Yeah, you heard me.  Snowmobiles! (pause) So what do we do?  Chase 'em on foot?? ALL EYES TURN at the blare of a horn.  The COPS peer down long corridor of the cross street -- and see a STRANGE BL VEHICLE barreling toward them at 90 MPH, with no intentio stopping... THE BATMOBILE!!  COPS dive left and right.  A split-secon later... ...a FORTY-FOOT JET of NOVA-INTENSITY FLAME erupts from t front of the jet-black supercar -- instantaneously DISSOL the drift that blocks the entrance to the park -- turning ice and snow on the paths before it into water! The BATMOBILE screams past in the wink of an eye.  The CO get to their feet; cold as it is, they're  sweating .  One of them mops his brow and announces, dumfounded:
...That was  Batman .
COP II yanks COP I into the nearest squad car, and the ot follow suit.  ENGINES REV.  As long as the BATMOBILE's cl a path, they might as well join in the chase...

TWO BURLY TEENAGERS -- both dressed in RED BERETS and PAR with BLACK BATMAN SWEATSHIRTS visible underneath -- are trudging along the path when they're STARTLED by a pair o speeding SKIDOOS.  Moments later, they spot a RED GLOW on horizon... ...and their JAWS DROP as the BATMOBILE roars into view, BURNING OFF THE SNOW IN ITS PATH.  Thrilled beyond words, WHOOP WITH GLEE, slapping high-fives as the car streaks p

His face is weirdly illuminated by the flame still spitti from the front of the car.  Cool as ever -- approaching t chase as a simple problem in logic -- he checks a radar display on his dashboard and sees FIVE BLIPS.

The cops follow along in BATMAN's path.  The lead car LOS CONTROL and plows headlong into a drift.  The DRIVER jams pedal, but his rear wheels end up digging a deep rut in t ice.  He sits there cursing, pumping the accelerator as o COPS race past him on foot.
The various ROBBERS have spread out, their vehicles BOUND over the hilly terrain of the park.  He spots two of them ahead; as he draws closer, they PART WAYS, veering off to left and right...
PODS OPEN on the front fenders, and MISSILE LAUNCHERS rot into place.  The Batmobile fires a pair of HEAT-SEEKING TORPEDOS, which BURROW into the snow on either side and disappear.

The DRIVER looks back over his shoulder and sees what app to be a BLACK SHARK FIN plowing through the snow behind h GAINING FAST.  He takes evasive action, but the SHARK FIN always seems to follow.  Just as he approaches the crest hill... ...the TORPEDO slams into the rear of the SNOWMOBILE.  Th force of impact knocks the ROBBER cleanly off.  His LOOT in the snow beside him, but the SNOWMOBILE keeps going -- sailing over the crest of the hill and striking the rocks beyond with a deafening EXPLOSION.

This ROBBER's a little smarter than his buddy.  When he s the shark fin on his tail, he noses his snowmobile off in GROVE OF TREES.  The trees are too closely spaced for the torpedo to maneuver; it strikes the nearest tree trunk an explodes harmlessly. The ROBBER is feeling good about himself, because the Batmobile can't follow either.  But BATMAN has a Plan B. he drives alongside the grove, he HITS THE ACCELERATOR, passing the snowmobile on its left.  A STEEL SPIKE attach a cable launches from the side of the Batmobile and WEDGE ITSELF into a distant TREE. The cable goes taut, and the tree TOPPLES -- directly int path of the second SNOWMOBILE.  The vehicle crashes into trunk, and the hapless ROBBER goes cartwheeling head-over heels into a drift. In the distance, COPS appear -- racing to the scene on fo ready for mop-up duty.  BATMAN kills the flamethrower, hi the brakes, and FISHTAILS, doing a quick 180 on the snow. He's just spotted fresh quarry: snowmobiles three and fou whizzing over a rolling white pasture in the distance.

We're at a makeshift CAMPSITE -- where a cluster of HOMEL PEOPLE are burning refuse in a garbage can to keep warm. look on in puzzlement as the two SNOWMOBILES whiz past an disappear over a crest of a hill...

They bounce down the hillside and SKID -- arriving at the of a frozen-over LAKE.  With the roar of the Batmobile be them, the two DRIVERS get the same idea simultaneously. Smiling, they rev their engines and set out over the surf of the lake. Now the Batmobile crests the ridge.  The car's weight tip suddenly and it begins to skid down the hill toward the l BATMAN sees what's happening and kills the flamethrower j in time -- but he can't brake the car on the snowy slope. prow of the Batmobile slides out onto the edge of the lak -- and under its weight, the ICE begins to crack.  The le front tire takes a sudden dip -- and worse yet, the car i sliding forward.

He shifts frantically from drive to reverse, trying to ro the car out of its predicament, but his rear wheels find purchase.  He can hear the ice cracking beneath him. Grimacing, he throws a switch on the dashboard --

-- and the trunk pops open.  An industrial-strength GRAPP HOOK shoots upward and digs in at a point beyond the cres the hill; and a concealed WINCH ASSEMBLY begins to grind hauling the Batmobile uphill, out of danger.
Suspended just above the icy lake, he sees the SNOWMOBILE vanishing into the distance.  He opens (yet another) pane the dashboard...

The ROBBERS give each other a big thumbs-up.  They're alm halfway across the lake now and the Batmobile is disabled All at once they hear a strange WHISTLING overhead... Fireworks?  No, it's a THERMITE BOMB -- rocketing past th hitting the ice some forty feet ahead and EXPLODING GAUDI JAGGED CHUNKS OF ICE break free and SHIFT in the frigid w -- and the ROBBERS are skidding into the drink before the know what's hit them.

The last of the robbers is SANTA CLAUS -- his big sack fi not with toys, but precious stones.  He approaches the ed the park, negotiating his way through a maze of rocky outcroppings.  He squirts out from behind a boulder into clearing... ...and GASPS in PANIC as a SEARING BURST OF FLAME erupts behind him.  The BATMOBILE speeds out from the other side the boulder; SANTA twists his accelerator, desperately tr to build up speed. As it is, he's barely managing to stay ahead of the flamethrower.  But the jet of flame suddenly DIES; the HO the Batmobile rises half a foot -- -- and TWIN PROJECTILES launch into the air.  A heavy NET strung between them -- and it lands SMACK ON TOP OF SANTA CLAUS, entangling the snowmobile and stopping him in his tracks. Immobilized, he watches through the net in horror as the Batmobile barrels down.  When the great black machine is almost atop him -- -- it stops on a dime six inches from his heavily-padded frame.

The COPS are spread out near the entrance.  They've round the other ROBBERS and returned most of the loot.  They he dull ROAR in the distance... ...and a few seconds later the BATMOBILE streaks into vie dragging the NET behind it -- SANTA, his loot, and his snowmobile, all tied up in one tidy parcel. At the entrance to the park, the NET detaches itself from Batmobile, dumping SANTA into the hands of the waiting CO Without stopping, the BATMOBILE roars out of the park and vanishes whence it came.  A mildly-humiliated COP turns t colleague and SHRUGS:
...Merry Christmas. The second COP points to SANTA, still struggling in the n
Gift-wrapped and everything.
TV MINICAM CREWS are camped out on the steps of City Hall with a sizable crowd watching from the street.  COMMISSIO GORDON is reading from a prepared statement.

After a high-speed chase -- over $750,000 in precious jewels were recovered intact by the police force -- working in concert with Batman. At the sound of Batman's name, a CHANTING goes up in the crowd:

GORDON winces and lets out a sigh.  The CHANTERS are a gr of pugnacious, well-muscled KIDS, late teens and early twenties, all dressed in identical garb: black Batman SWEATSHIRTS and little red Guardian-angel BERETS.  They'r obviously members of the same club -- just like the guys saw in the park. GORDON waits for them to shut up, but they don't; so he g the mike and speaks slowly and distinctly, trying to be h over the din.
I would like to stress -- that while this city enjoys a special relationship with Batman -- (louder) -- we do not condone  vigilantism

(practically screaming) -- IN ANY FORM. It's no use.  He's totally drowned out by the RED BERETS, continue to shout and shake their fists.  Giving up, he returns the mike to a REPORTER and marches up the steps i huff.  The RED BERETS CHEER.
The evening news: a live, on-the-spot interview from Goth Square.  A superimposed GRAPHIC identifies a surly kid in RED BERET as "MIKE SEKOWSKY -- SPOKESPERSON -- ORDER OF T
And hey!  Where does this -- (BLEEP; expletive deleted) -- Gordon get off calling us
We're not breakin' any laws.  We're a group of concerned citizens, that's all -- just like Batman .
You people are nothing but hoodlums!
Hey, lady -- we're out here on patrol riskin' our necks to  protect old biddies like you. (into mike) If this lame-o Gordon could do his  job
MORE CATCALLS from the crowd.  The picture jumps suddenly minicam is jostled; some sort of SCUFFLE appears to be breaking out.  Before it does, CAMERA PULLS BACK from the screen, placing us in:

where ALFRED THE BUTLER is watching the Sekowsky intervie with extreme dismay.  As he trims the crusts from a pair hearty watercress sandwiches, he SLICES HIS FINGER OPEN. ALFRED makes a pained face -- it's all Sekowsky's fault. Onscreen, the fracas continues; SEKOWSKY has recommandeer the mike... SEKOWSKY (on TV)
We're provin' that the spirit of Batman is alive in this city.  We're gonna  take back the streets

SEKOWSKY raises a fist.  Behind him, his CRONIES begin to chant: "TAKE BACK THE STREETS!  TAKE BACK THE STREETS!" Incensed, sucking on his finger, ALFRED moves to the TV a flicks it off. He turns on the radio in search of something more soothin "Good King Wenceslas" pipes through the manor; smiling, A sets the sandwich plate alongside a steaming kettle on a Sterling silver tea service.

The CAROL CONTINUES UNDERNEATH as ALFRED, white linen dra over one forearm, sets the tea tray down on his master's mahogany desk.  He digs in his pocket for a key and unloc side drawer. The drawer contains a stack of yellowed, aging NEWPAPER CLIPPINGS -- among them one which reads "THOMAS WAYNE MURDERED: Prominent Doctor, Wife Slain in Robbery. Unidentified Gunman Leaves Child Unharmed."  ALFRED digs around beneath the clippings and finds a concealed SWITCH the rear of the drawer. Gears grind, and a sectional bookcase detaches itself fro wall -- sliding out a couple of feet to reveal a STONE STAIRWAY which descends into darkness...

Descending the stone stairs, ALFRED arrives in the Batcav "Good King Wenceslas" is on the speakers down here as wel Across a catwalk the BATMOBILE rests on its little platea wrapped in a tarp. ALFRED clears some space on a lab table and sets the tea service down.  He glances up at the bank of video monitor sees SEKOWSKY, still babbling, on several channels simultaneously.  He scans the cave, but there's no trace BRUCE. ALFRED

Sir?  -- MASTER BRUCE?? As if in response, BATS screech and flutter in the distan recesses of the cavern.  ALFRED turns suddenly and sees B behind him, suspended from a thin filament wire, RISING O A BOTTOMLESS ABYSS. BRUCE

I'm not deaf, Alfred.  I hear you. He's wearing his civvie -- tweed pants and cashmere sweat but he's got the utility belt, with its spring-action ree buckled about his waist.  Clutching a bundle, he hangs in midair for a moment, dangling over the void.  ALFRED slow regains his composure: ALFRED
I took the liberty of preparing tea. (indicating tbe monitors) I take it you've been watching the news? BRUCE, still dangling, glances up at the SEKOWSKY intervi and nods. BRUCE

Yeah...lot of crazy people in this world. BRUCE rocks back and forth to build up momentum.  He kick on the nearest stone outcropping, lands gracefully on the Batcave floor, and unbuckles his belt.  Preoccupied, he d his mysterious bundle on the lab table: a roll of black fabric, and a cluster of lightweight, hollow ALUMINUM ROD connected by what appears to be SURGICAL TUBING. ALFRED
I should inform you...Christmas is approaching, and we've received our annual solicitation from the Fireman's Toy Fund. (eyeing the equipment) If I may inquire...? BRUCE

Oh, yeah.  Watch this. BRUCE hits a trigger on a tiny gas canister attached to t tubing.  The tubing inflates and the rods spring erect -- stiffening, wing-like, into something which looks remarka like the skeleton of an umbrella. ALFRED
Most ingenious, sir.  What exactly  it? BRUCE
What does it look like? ALFRED
To the untrained eye, sir, it looks remarkably like...the skeleton of an umbrella. Sounds good.  BRUCE eyes his new invention, thinks it ove smiles slyly. BRUCE
Good guess, Alfred.  That's exactly right. BRUCE hits the trigger, and the rods WILT with a hiss.  H sits at his lab table; ALFRED unfolds a napkin on his lap pours a cup of tea. ALFRED
Splendid, sir, and if I may say, I'm glad you're putting your time to such productive use. (beat) Now -- the Toy Fund.  Our contribution last year was a half-million dollars... BRUCE
We can do better than that. ALFRED

Then there's the foster-parents program... the Gotham homeless crusade... BRUCE nods abstractedly and tucks into his sandwich.  He oddly preoccupied -- not exactly melancholy, but his thou are obviously a million miles away.  ALFRED looks on, concerned: ALFRED (cont.)
Is something troubling you, sir? BRUCE
Yeah...the holidays, I guess.  Always gets me thinking about... (he changes the subject) And to tell you the truth, I'm a little -- concerned about Vicki. ALFRED
(anxiously) Miss Vale, sir...? BRUCE

Yeah.  I've been thinking about it lately. Thinking about it a lot... (gravely; shaking his head) ...and I still can't figure out what to get her for Christmas. BRUCE shoots ALFRED a solemn, perplexed look -- and ALFRE heaves an audible sigh of relief as we

TIGHT ON a stack of COOPS and CAGES, piled high against a concrete wall.  Each cage -- and there are at least two d of them -- contains a twittering BIRD: starlings, pigeons cardinals, titwillows... CAMERA PULLS BACK from the bars of the cages to reveal a ODD FIGURE in prison greys.  A CANARY, perched on his shoulder, SINGS HAPPILY as he stands in front of a grimy, cracked mirror, plastering back his hair, BUFFING HIS NAI with quick, birdlike strokes. MR. BONIFACE is beak-nosed, epicene, and so fat that it s his skin should burst; the adjective that comes to mind i "obscene."  Despite his eccentric appearance, he comports himself with overblown, theatrical dignity.  Fastidious a preening, he does not suffer insults lightly. CAMERA PULLS BACK FURTHER -- through another set of bars and we realize that MR. BONIFACE is himself caged.  A PRI GUARD arrives to slide back his cell door... GUARD
Up and at 'em, Pengy.  -- Pengy? MR. BONIFACE pointedly ignores the GUARD, refusing to acknowledge the odious (if wholly appropriate) nickname. GUARD (cont.)
Boniface ... MR. BONIFACE finally turns.  With an expression of extrem distaste, he affixes a MONOCLE over one eye, returns the canary to its cage and allows himself to be ushered out.
MR. BONIFACE and his ATTORNEY sit at a long table across the WARDEN and the members of the PAROLE BOARD. PAROLE OFFICER
You want to return the money you stole. BONIFACE
Intact.  The map will show you where it's buried. The PAROLE OFFICER stares skeptically at a hand-scrawled PAROLE OFFICER
All of it.  Forty-two million dollars. MR. BONIFACE stares down humbly at the table -- as if he the mere mention of his transgression too embarrassing to bear. PAROLE OFFICER II
Why this sudden change of heart? MR. BONIFACE

Gentlemen, I want my debt to be repaid in full.  I want to be a part of civilized society! (oozing sincerity) Prison life is not for me.  The guilt, the fear, the constant shame...one meets a disturbingly low class of people. PAROLE OFFICER II
Sure, but -- forty-two million dollars?? MR. BONIFACE nods plaintively.  It's quite a perfomlance. dabs at his face with a handkerchief; it's hot in here, a he's the delicate type... WARDEN
His record's clean.  Thirteen years without an incident. ATTORNEY

I'd like to point out, my client's put his time to good use.  A student of ornithology...articles published in several respected journals... The PAROLE OFFICER thumbs through a stack of magazines:  Bird World
Ornithological Review
Beaks And Feathers
Nest Egg . MR. BONIFACE
Birds, yes.  My only source of solace. PAROLE OFFICER
In light of this rather extraordinary gesture, I see no reason not to endorse your application for parole. BONIFACE

Thank you, sir.  You won't regret it. MR. BONIFACE shakes hands with the members of the PAROLE BOARD.  As the GUARDS escort him out, a BLACK MYNAH BIRD SQUAWKS LOUDLY from its cage in the corner of the office: MYNAH
CHUCKLES all around.  On his way out the ATTORNEY gesture toward the mynah -- and BEAMS at the parole board: ATTORNEY
Personally trained by my client.

Free time -- the cell doors are open and the convicts are milling around in the common area.  T-BONE, 220 lbs. of d hulking beef, saunters up to his cell and finds his bunkm MR. BONIFACE, staring at a stack of EMPTY CAGES.  BONIFAC whirls on him suddenly, his face beet-red, APOPLECTIC WIT
MR. BONIFACE
Where are my birds
T-BONE
Shit, Pengy.  I let 'em  go . MR. BONIFACE
Hermione.  My canary.  It's the dead of winter! T-BONE flops casually on his bunk, obviously enjoying MR. BONIFACE's profound distress. T-BONE

They were all cooped up.  With you leaving and all -- seemed like the humane thing to do. BONIFACE'S GAZE FALLS on a corner of the cell.  He spots scattering of YELLOW FEATHERS -- a patch of FRESH BLOOD. a supreme effort of restraint, he turns and forces a smil MR. BONIFACE
I see.  -- You might as well have this.  I won't be needing it... He tosses a SONY WALKMAN to T-BONE, who flicks it on.  Th strains of CLASSICAL MUSIC are audible through the earphones... T-BONE

Well, thanks, Pengy.  No hard feelings. (chuckling to himself) Y'know, I'm gonna miss that pudgy little ass of yours. T-BONE tunes the Walkman to a rock station, slips the hea on, grins from his bunk.  TWO GUARDS arrive.  As they esc him out, MR. BONIFACE mutters: MR. BONIFACE
You won't miss it long.

It's fifteen degrees outside as MR. BONIFACE -- aka THE PENGUIN -- waddles forth from the prison gates, regally attired in cutaway and pin-stripes.  He pauses to inhale deep lungful of the icy air; then, with a smile of exhilaration, he removes his coat and STRETCHES -- spread his wings, REVELING in the cold. A STRETCH LIMO pulls up.  Two identically gaunt and vultu like DANDIES, formally dressed, with bowler hats and umbrellas, step out to meet him.  These two gentlemen -- and FRACK -- serve as the Penguin's general factoti and "business managers." FRICK
Welcome back, Mr. Boniface. PENGUIN
Mr. Frick.  Mr. Frack.  Our years of planning are about to pay off.
Now that he's loose, the PENGUIN's rapacious side is begi to show.  His eyes twinkle with greed as he contemplates own ingenuity. PENGUIN
I take it they found the money all right? FRACK
We buried it exactly as you specified. $42,271,009... PENGUIN
How much have we got left? FRICK reaches into his coat for a BALANCE SHEET. FRICK
Let's see -- an initial capitalization of 42 million and change, compounded over thirteen years, at an annual return of just under sixteen percent -- PENGUIN
Fine, fine.  How  much
FRICK

Seventy-nine million.  -- Excluding the sum we buried. THE PENGUIN lets out a dry, heaving CHORTLE, midway betwe normal laugh and a DUCK'S QUACK.  He checks his watch and reaches into his pocket for a small ELECTRONIC DEVICE. PENGUIN
Speaking of burials...

T-BONE on work detail.  He's got the Walkman on and he's shoveling snow to the beat.  He winces, and removes the headphones... The MUSIC he was listening to has been replaced by an eer high-pitched WHINE.  He's twisting the knob, trying to fi the station he was tuned to, when a PIGEON dives down STR AT HIS HEAD. T-BONE

He drops the shovel as the bird STRIKES, glancing off his head.  Before he can react, THREE MORE PIGEONS have swoop down at him, PECKING at his head and shoulders in a frenz He lets out a HOWL and staggers through the prison yard i frenzy.  DOZENS of PIGEONS are pouring over the prison wa SHRIEKING HIDEOUSLY, descending on him.  He falls to the ground screaming for help, but the other prisoners run li rabbits, terrified... By the time the GUARDS come racing across the courtyard, T-BONE's no longer even visible.  There's just a swarming man-shaped mass of PIGEONS, pecking away, flapping their insanely.  Covering their faces as they move in, the GUAR blow their whistles -- BEAT AT the pigeons with billy clu All at once, the PIGEONS take off  en masse -- leaving T-BONE's mutilated corpse sprawled in the yard.  A GUARD notices t Walkman, picks up the earphones to listen, and hears noth but ROCK MUSIC -- "Surfin' Bird" by the Trashmen.  Bird b bird, bird is the word...

An AERIAL VIEW of the LIMO as it cruises down the deserte road leading away from the prison.  It disappears from vi and all at once the frame is filled with PIGEONS, great squalling FLOCKS of them, dutifully following their maste he makes his way back to Gotham City.
ALFRED opens the front door and finds a bundled-up VICKI on the portico, red-cheeked, flushed, and happy.  She pul him forward, gives him a quick peck on the cheek. VICKI

Guess what, Alfred.  I think I found a present for Bruce. She's got a long, skinny GIFT BOX propped up against the exterior wall.  At first it doesn't want to fit through t door -- it must be eight feet long -- but with ALFRED's h she gets it inside.  The faithful butler stares curiously this odd-shaped gift... VICKI (cont.)
Skis.  -- Don't let on, okay? ALFRED
He won't hear a word of it from me. VICKI
He's such a nightmare to shop for.  -- What do you  get him year after year, Alfred? ALFRED
(conspiratorially) I find you can't go wrong with surveillance equipment.  Let me put this under the tree... VICKI
Not so fast. She reaches into the pocket of her coat and pulls out ano small gift.  ALFRED stares at the tag -- "TO ALFRED, LOVE VICKI" -- and tries to suppress a HUGE GRIN. ALFRED
Why, Miss Vale -- ! VOICE FROM BEHIND
What's all this? ALFRED and VICKI turn.  It's BRUCE, dressed for dinner, marching down the long stairway in the entry hall.  VICKI waves frantically. VICKI
Don't look.  It's your present. VICKI rushes over to embrace him.  He gapes at the long s box -- BRUCE
What'd you get me?  Kareem Abdul-Jabbar? VICKI frowns and gives him a kiss.  She nestles up agains him.  WHISPERS in his ear: VICKI

I'm going to give you the happiest Christmas you've ever had. Still in the clinch, BRUCE shoots a look at ALFRED.  Taki the hint, ALFRED clears his throat and bends to pick up o end of the ski box.  He backs out of the entry hall, drag the box before him...

FIRES burn in garbage cans.  TENTS and LEAN-TOS dot the s landscape.  Men, women, and children wander aimlessly, huddling against the cold. An army of the HOMELESS has set up camp in Gotham Park. the nearby periphery, PICKETERS -- half concerned citizen half down-and-outers -- are marching the sidewalks, keepi candlelight VIGIL.  Hand-lettered placards read: "SAVE TH

head_text.subj: PARK." "PARKS ARE FOR PEOPLE." "THIS PARK IS OUR HOME."

text: The source of the protest?  A towering SIGN posted in a c of the park, announcing the imminent consuuction of a new luxury highrise -- the GOTHAM PARK TOWERS -- a project of Construction, Inc. A LAMBORGHINI sits at a traffic light nearby...
BRUCE and VICKI, dressed for dinner, stare out at the demonstration. VICKI
Homeless. (beat) I was just down here Tuesday.  Seems like there's more every day. BRUCE starts to say something, but can't think of anythin say. VICKI (cont.)
Christmas time.  And they say there's over a thousand people living in the park already. BRUCE
-- Yeah. The light changes.  BRUCE throws the car into gear and -- the next intersection -- turns the car right, into the pa

Despite the name, it's a tony little bistro catering to Gotham's elite.  A PANHANDLER, underdressed for the cold, been hustling the customers as they come out; a couple of PARKING ATTENDANTS are trying to drag him discreetly away BRUCE'S CAR pulls up. A VALET opens the car for BRUCE and VICKI, who look on in concern as the PANHANDLER gets the bum's rush.  The liver DOORMAN shrugs apolagetically -- sorry for the inconvenie -- as they enter.

Post-dinner.  VICKI's got a sheaf of PHOTOS spread out on table in front of BRUCE -- shots of Gotham's HOMELESS, be forcibly evicted from slum dwellings, erecting their SHANTYTOWNS in Gotham Park. VICKI

They're already razing the tenements and SRO's downtown.  These people don't have anyplace else to go. (beat) If the city starts selling off the park... BRUCE takes a good long look at his opulent surroundings. HUGE WINDOWS open on a serene and picturesque view of the park; CAMPFIRES flicker in the distance... BRUCE
-- Yeah.  I guess I'll pass on dessert. VICKI
(taking his hand) Bruce, you do a lot more than most people even dream of. BRUCE
Sure.  Comes off the top of my taxes -- VICKI
That's not what I meant. They exchange a long silent look.  Of course she's referr to Batman.  Still, the argument doesn't hold much water w BRUCE. BRUCE
-- What I "do" doesn't come close to the root of the problem, Vicki. (long pause) I'm just a Band-Aid. VOICE FROM BEHIND
Bruce!  It's been ages! VICKI turns -- and rapidly closes her photo folder. Millionaire construction magnate RANDALL SHAW is in the restaurant table-hopping, and he's just glommed onto BRUC BRUCE
Randall.  You remember Vicki.  -- How's the construction business? SHAW
The park tower?  All systems go.   If we can get the junkies and winos cleared out... (a big grin) Not too late to get in on the deal. BRUCE
I'll think about it. SHAW

Say, Walter Barrett's due back from Europe.  We should all get together at the club. (clapping him on the shoulder) Nice to see you again,  Miss Veal. "Miss Veal" maintains a big phony smile as SHAW moves off the next table.  She murmurs to BRUCE through clenched te VICKI
What a pig. BRUCE
I've known him since he was seven years old.  He was a pig then too. VICKI
Now he wants to gobble up the  park ... (shivering) Bruce -- isn't there something you can  do about people like that? BRUCE
What, tie him up with a bat-rope? VICKI
No, you idiot.  I meant  you
Bruce . BRUCE nods -- oh, yeah.  Subtle distinction.

BRUCE and VICKI emerge from the restaurant.  He hands his parking stub to a VALET.  A crowd's beginning to form in lot outside... The red-and-blue bubble of a POLICE CAR is flashing a sho distance off, near the entrance to the park.  TWO RED BER in full Order-of-the-Bat regalia, look on as a recently-m WOMAN JOGGER gives her statement to the investigating COP BRUCE and VICKI, intrigued by the Batman-wannabes, move a little closer -- within eavesdropping range: RED BERET I
We were on patrol.  Saw the whole thing. JOGGER
I was attacked.  Three men in ski masks -- COP I
(indicating the RED BERETS) And these two broke it up? JOGGER
These two??  They ran like rabbits.  I never  saw anybody take off so -- RED BERET II
Hey!  Somebody had to go for the cops. COP II
You.  SHUT UP, all right?? (to the JOGGER) Lady, who was it that bailed you out?? JOGGER

kid .  Thirteen or fourteen tops.  He just came out of nowhere and -- tore into 'em. (shaking her head) It was so quick I didn't even see his face. Nearby, VICKI shoots a highly quizzical look at BRUCE, wh responds with a mystified shrug.  Her professional curios piqued, she wanders over to introduce herself to the JOGG An exasperated COP leads the RED BERETS away from the cri site: RED BERET I
Dumb shit.  Shouldn'ta been jogging in the park at night anyway. (sullenly) Look around you.  It's fulla  bums . BRUCE gestures at the RED BERET's Batman sweatshirt as he passes. BRUCE
Nice outfit. RED BERET I
Piss off, geek.

Snow blankets the abandoned warehouses rimming Gotham Har FOGHORNS blare in the distance as a pair of STILETTO HEEL totally inappropriate for the weather -- click across the sidewalk and pause at mid-block, where a wide wooden plan leads down from street level to a seedy hole-in-the-wall the WHARF RAT.
A roughneck joint, about as trendy as the average bait sh The clientele consists primarily of surly types who are s up for their next tattoo.  A TV over the bar is tuned to late news: ANCHORWOMAN

...and tomorrow, the city's power elite will be turning out in force to greet millionaire industrialist Walter Barrett, who returns to Gotham after a five-year stay in Europe... The BARTENDER switches to a hockey game, because none of rowdies at the bar give a shit about Walter Barrett.  Non that is, except for a strapping young bruiser named RICKY gets up and makes his way to a pay phone in the corner. Moments later, the owner of the high heels enters; she op her black fur coat and unwraps her muffler, revealing exo vaguely Eurasian features.  She's dark and elegant, fine- boned, regal of bearing -- and her name, though we don't it yet, is SELINA KYLE. She's not the kind of girl who typically frequents the Wh Rat, and so her entrance creates quite a stir.  A LONGSHO at the nearby pool table misses his shot and digs a rut i felt.  Two blowsy WHORES size her up territorially as she finds an open stool at the bar and settles in with serene indifference. The regulars, of course, are all but licking their chops. only guy in the joint who hasn't noticed her yet is RICKY who's still on the phone: RICKY
Yo.  Ricky here.  What's the haps? In mid-conversation he notices SELINA.  She smiles inviti -- right at him.  Mildly startled, he smiles back. RICKY (cont.)
Midnight.  No sweat.  See you then. He hangs up eagerly.  Then, with a deep breath, he hitche his pants and swaggers over to SELINA's end of the bar. SELINA
Well.  "Ricky," is it? RICKY
How'd you know that? SELINA
I heard you on the phone.  Talking to your girlfriend. RICKY
Girlfriend?  No, no.  That was  business . SELINA makes a big show of peeling off her gloves. SELINA

If you've got time for a little pleasure ...maybe you'd like to buy me a drink. She clasps his hand.  His EYES BUG OUT.  Three enormous r a diamond bracelet -- there must be several thousand in r on her left hand alone.  RICKY gapes at the sparklers, bedazzled. RICKY
Jeez -- they look almost real. SELINA
Why wouldn't they be? RICKY is not the smoothest guy around, and his line of th is all too evident.  He swallows hard and tries not to st RICKY
You'd have to be crazy.  Nobody'd wear the real thing to a dive like this. SELINA

Oh, they're real, all right.  So are these. She waves her FINGERNAILS -- long, polished, and talon-sh -- in front of his eyes.  With lightning speed, before he react, she pins his wrist to the bar -- and with one quic stroke carves a THIN BLOODY STRIPE in the back of his han SELINA's eyes flash as he gasps in shock.  He tries to je his hand away, but he can't break her grip.  Then -- her dominance firmly established -- she releases his hand wit coy, Cheshire-cat smile. SELINA (cont.)

Weren't we going to have a drink? He blinks, forces a chuckle, smiles unsteadily.  She take wounded hand, lifts it slowly to her mouth, and LAPS GENT the blood.  RICKY is hypnotized. She's got an odd way of flirting, but RICKY finds it some -- intriguing.  He dabs at his hand with a napkin and sig to the BARTENDER.

Just after midnight; the snow's still failing, the waters icy, and the wharfs are deserted -- almost.  A small STEA is docked at Pier 31, and the deck is lined with THUGS -- mean, ugly, and heavily armed. A similar contingent of gun-toting GOONS is waiting to gr them on the dock below.  The boys on the dock hoist ASSAU RIFLES as the BOAT THUGS extend a gangplank.  Something m is about to happen... The CHIEF DOCK GOON gestures to his LIEUTENANT, who grabs black MEDICAL BAG.  Hands raised, the two of them start u gangplank. Throughout all this, the DOCK GOONS keep their guns train the BOAT THUGS, covering their buddies.  One of them turn a colleague: DOCK GOON I
Where's that goddam Ricky? DOCK GOON II
Probably out gettin' laid.  And here we are freezin' our balls off...
The LIEUTENANT unloads chemical testing gear from his doc bag.  The lead BOAT THUG gestures to a stack of SHIPPING CRATES which rest atop a large NET spread out across the BOAT THUG I
You pick. The CHIEF GOON selects a crate at random.  Two BOAT THUGS it on its side and, using a crowbar, pry off a FALSE BOTT revealing a dozen packets of WHITE POWDER.
We're now watching the scene from a vantage point atop a ramshackle boathouse at water's edge.  Down on the deck o steamboat, the LIEUTENANT goes to work testing the merchandise. LIEUTENANT
It's pure.
A BLACK SILHOUETTE is peering down from the boathouse roo The mysterious watcher ducks quickly out of sight; the on details that register are a pair of ominously familiar PO EARS... CHIEF GOON (O.S.)

Let's do it. He gestures to his boys on the dock. A CRANE-AND-WINCH assembly rotates into place over the deck -- and the BOAT THUGS gather up the corners of the netting and attach the the big hook. BOAT THUG I

Hold it.  Let's see the money. Down on the wharf, a DOCK GOON kneels beside a metal suit and opens it.  Lots of long green inside.  The BOAT THUG signals thumbs up, and the CRATES rise into the air as th goon with the suitcase starts up the gangplank.
The goon with the suitcase marches up.  Beyond him, in th distance, a LITHE BLACK SHADOW vaults off the boathouse r and makes a silent, graceful landing on the long shaft of CRANE.
The moment of maximum tension: grim faces all around, eve holding a gun on someone else as the suitcase arrives on and crane swings over the pier.
Razor-sharp, CHROME-STEEL TALONS slash suddenly through t air.

The netting GIVES WAY, and TWO DOZEN SHIPPING CRATES rain onto the pier, CRUSHING two DOCK GOONS underneath.  The c explode into splinters, littering the dock with drugs and random ART OBJECTS as the other DOCK GOONS scatter in pan

Nobody knows quite what's going on.  Panicking, the GOON the suitcase full of money turns tail and dives for the gangplank.  BOAT THUG I sees him and squeezes off a quick shot.  Winged, the GOON topples off the gangplank and hit drink, suitcase and all. Pandemonium.  All at once, everyone's OPENING FIRE.  Thin he's been double-crossed, BOAT THUG I turns on the CHIEF and SHOOTS HIM TWICE at point-blank range. BOAT THUG I

(to another BOAT THUG) Go after it.  Get the money.  GO!! He raises his gun, and the second BOAT THUG dutifully obe diving off the deck into a hail of gunfire.  Everyone's ducking for cover.  BOAT THUG I barks orders at the pilothouse: BOAT THUG I
Soltar las amarras!  -- CAST OFF!! ANOTHER BOAT THUG

BOAT THUG I whirls, just in time to see a SHADOWY FIGURE landing cat-like on the deck mere yards away.  Clad in in black leather from head to toe, the intruder's face is concealed by what appears to be a BONDAGE MASK.  Studded, openings for the eyes and mouth, it spans one incongruous touch: a pair of POINTED CAT EARS. She bares her teeth and HISSES. It's a woman. BOAT THUG I is momentarily mesmerized.  In the time it ta him to lift his gun, she's produced a CAT-O'-NINE-TAILS. SNAPS it at him: REELS HIM IN; and with one lethal stroke RAKES her steel talons across his face and throat.  He sl to the deck, lifeless. The other BOAT THUG rushes her; she catches him under the with a sudden upthrust, LIFTS HIM INTO THE AIR, and sends toppling into the water. The gangplank falls aside as the steamboat pulls away fro pier.  She hoists an abandoned ASSAULT RIFLE, SCATTERS th DOCK GOONS with a round of automatic fire, and VAULTS off boat -- landing in a graceful crouch on the edge of the p Most of the DOCK GOONS have taken flight, but a few unluc specimens remain behind.  She somersaults forward; takes goon off his feet with a crack of the whip; knocks anothe the dock with a twirling high-kick to the jaw; sends two reeling with swift talon-slashes.  The whole frenzied mop action takes just under ten seconds.  Alone at last, she stands back to survey the scene. Counting the stiff's on the boat -- which is now receding the harbor -- there must be well over a dozen dead.  The is speckled with red.  A half-dozen bodies lie sprawled i their own blood; one of them, the lone survivor, is face- and softly MOANING. Retracting her steel claws, the MASKED WOMAN crouches ami wreckage of the smashed shipping crates.  BINDLES OF WHIT POWDER -- millions of dollars' worth -- are scattered all about the pier, but she couldn't seem less interested. Instead, she's checking the MANIFEST NUMBERS stamped on t sides of the crates. She finds crate #18396-BB and rummages among its contents until she comes up with a carefully-wrapped parcel.  She it carefully and holds it up for inspection.  The statuet a RAVEN -- carved from solid onyx -- glistens in the moonlight. The WOMAN pauses long enough to slip a small CARD in the MOANING PUNK's back pocket.  Then, cradling the raven und one arm, she dashes off on silent cat feet. A LANTERN approaches.  It's an OLD SALT -- some kind of hapless night watchman -- and his face goes bone-white at sight of the carnage on the docks.  He kneels beside the moaning punk, turns the body over, and GASPS -- because t PUNK'S FACE has been CLAWED TO SHREDS. PUNK
Murcielago.  MURCIELAGO!!

The unique chamber in which we find ourselves is alive wi the flutter and song of COLD-WEATHER BIRDS -- dozens of t all chirping, flitting about in the rafters, alighting on special perches mounted in the walls. At the center of this penthouse room is a vast sunken POO ARCTIC TERNS loll on the surrounding rocks as a LACKEY wi wheelbarrow empties cracked ice into the already-frigid w Carefully landscaped, it looks like the penguin exhibit a Gotham Zoological Gardens. A MASSIVE, INDISTINCT SHAPE glides beneath the surface. not a whale; it's too pink.  It is, instead, the PENGUIN and as he breaks the surface, sputtering, he sees FRICK standing in the open doorway. FRICK
Mr. Boniface?  Your...visitor has arrived. PENGUIN

Thank you, Mr. Frick.  Show her in. The PENGUIN moves to the edge of the sunken pool.  Two of LACKEYS swivel a CROSSBAR, which hangs from the ceiling b long chain, into place over his head.  He grasps it with hands -- and the crossbar RISES, hoisting his formidable out of the water.

FRICK leads the VISITOR down a long corridor lined on eit side with BIRD CAGES -- exotic songbirds with brilliantly plumage.  CAMERA TRACKS ALONG behind her, and although we can't see her face, there must be something distinctively feline about her -- because the BIRDS are shrieking and fluttering in their cages, RECOILING INSTINCTIVELY as she strolls past. FRICK opens a door and ushers her into...

Our visitor -- SELINA KYLE -- enters the penguin-pool roo Her teeth begin to chatter.  The big bay windows have bee thrown open, and SNOW is blowing in from outside. It's freezing in here. She sees the PENGUIN -- wearing a thin dressing gown and APRON outfitted with SEED POUCHES -- scattering birdseed the window ledge for the pigeons, totally oblivious to th cold.  He turns, throws his arms wide in greeting, kisses back of SELINA's hand. PENGUIN
Ah, Miss Kyle!  At last we meet. SELINA
At last we meet.  -- Pigeons? PENGUIN

Yes, they're common birds -- dirty, stupid, unattractive -- but they're very obedient, and they  do crap on people's heads.  May I? She extends a SHOPPING BAG.  The PENGUIN removes a parcel unwraps it, revealing the RAVEN STATUETTE.  He sets it on nearby desk, fondles it reverently...and BEAMS at SELINA. PENGUIN (cont.)
I see your reputation was not exaggerated. SELINA
I've located the others.  All but one. (shivering) I'm surprised you don't catch pneumonia -- ! With an apologetic smile, the PENGUIN pulls the windows s PENGUIN
My normal body temperature is ninety-two degrees.  Germs find me inhospitable. SELINA
I see why they call you the Penguin. PENGUIN
They may call me that...but rarely more than once.  Champagne? She nods.  He pours two glasses, hands one to SELINA, rai toast. PENGUIN (cont.)
My dear.  Here's to the  second biggest crime in the history of Gotham City.
COMMISSIONER GORDON and another cop, LT. EDDIE BULLOCK, a darkened antechamber adjacent to an interrogation room. BULLOCK

It wasn't about the drugs.  Whoever it was left thirty kilos sitting on the docks. They're watching, through a two-way glass panel, as a terrified man with a heavily-bandaged face tells his stor It's the lone survivor of the dock massacre, JULIO, and h voice is audible over a concealed intercom: JULIO (filter)
Un silueta negra -- con colmillos, y garras -- el demonio.  El murcielago.
GORDON
What's that he keeps saying? BULLOCK
"Murcielago."  -- Bat. GORDON
Nonsense.  That dock looked like a slaughter-house.  Batman's never committed murder. BULLOCK

We did find this in his back pocket. BULLOCK hands GORDON a CARD.  It reads: "THOSE WHO FEED O SOUL OF GOTHAM WILL SUFFER MY WRATH" -- and in lieu of a signature, there's a little black BAT-EMBLEM in the botto corner. While GORDON's staring at it, a POLICEMAN pokes his head POLICEMAN
Commissioner?  We've got Barrett.
A cubicle down the hall.  The splenetic WALTER BARRETT, millionaire industrialist, is fidgeting in his chair as G enters. BARRETT
Fine welcome.  These storm troopers of yours dragged me away from my coming-home party! (beat) I'd like to know the meaning of this -- GORDON
I'd like to know how thirty kilos of pure cocaine wound up concealed in your personal effects. BARRETT

Gordon -- I come from one of the oldest and most influential familles in Gotham. If you plan to accuse me of smuggling drugs, be my guest. (long, menacing pause) I'll have your badge before you leave this room. GORDON weighs the threat.  He nods to the COPS in attendance... GORDON
Book the son of a bitch. GORDON storms out.  BARRETT jumps out of his chair, but t COPS restrain him.  Outraged, he bats their hands away... BARRETT
I believe I'm still entitled to a phone call.

VICKI with her camera, squeezing off snaps.  She's standi behind a SAWHORSE, part of a crowd of onlookers at a down DEMOLITION SITE.  SURVEYORS and HARDHATS bustle about in VACANT LOT, a full city block in size, fenced off and str with rubble.  The only structure still standing is a lone decrepit TENEMENT BUILDING; a WRECKING BALL is poised abo it, ready to strike. A SIGN at one corner of the lot announces a forty-story O COMPLEX soon to be erected on this site by SHAW CONSTRUCT INC.  Down below is RANDALL SHAW HIMSELF, in necktie and hardhat, speaking into a WALKIE-TALKIE: SHAW

Come on!  Let's move it!  We're an hour behind as it is!! A few moments later, a CLUSTER OF PEOPLE emerge from the tenement building -- a mixed team of COPS and CONSTRUCTIO GOONS who are forcibly removing a DESTITUTE FAMILY from t condenmed building.  VICKI watches angrily...

A quick series of shots: the SQUATTERS wailing and strugg clinging to the doorways, unwilling to leave.  Their few belongings are packed in a couple of CARDBOARD BOXES, whi the cops heave rudely out onto the street.  Finally, the handcuffs and nightsticks come out...
A SURVEYOR grabs SHAW by the arm and points out the woman taking photos in the crowd.  SHAW recognizes her instantl His face turns into a mask of outrage -- as if he's been personally betrayed. SHAW
Jesus Christ, that's Bruce Wayne's bimbo! He makes eye contact with her.  VICKI stares back defiant He's about to stroll over and tell her off when a HARDHAT signals to him: HARDHAT
Phone call, Mr. Shaw.  Guy said it's urgent. SHAW
(to tbe SURVEYOR) Hold the ball.  I wanna hear it crash. He climbs into the cab of a nearby TRUCK, where he picks CELLULAR PHONE.
BARRETT's still in custody at the police station -- using one phone call to contact the construction magnate. BARRETT
It's me, Randall -- Walter Barrett.  I want you to call my attorney.  That was  my shipment they busted up last night. SHAW
Jesus, Walter, I -- (suddenly puzzled) Why are you calling  me
BARRETT
It's worse than that.  Somebody took my raven. SHAW stares at the phone in horrified disbelief.

SHE WATCHES as SHAW climbs out of the truck -- numb, in a daze.  He signals to the WRECKING BALL OPERATOR; a WHISTL blows, and the great iron ball knocks a MAMMOTH HOLE in t facade of the tenement. SHAW doesn't even stick around to watch it.  He scurries to his car at the end of the block.  VICKI, highly intrig gets it all on film...
VICKI's in a huddle with the Managing Editor, SCHULTZ, sh him her PHOTOS -- SHAW orchestrating the eviction of the SQUATTER FAMILY. SCHULTZ

Great stuff, but we're looking at a shitfight with our beloved publisher.  He and Shaw... (crossing his fingers) Old money sticks together. VICKI points to a photo of SHAW racing from the truck to car. VICKI
I'd sure like to know what shook him up so.  He was out of there like a scared rabbit... Just then, a reporter -- WILK -- rushes up excitedly to SCHULTZ's desk. WILK
Got a blind tip from downtown.  You know that massacre on the docks?   Batman . VICKI reacts in astonishment.  SCHULTZ's jaw drops -- thi hot . EDITOR
Whoa!  Is this on the level? WILK

Cops even got a note.  "Those who feed on the soul of Gotham will suffer my wrath!" (grinning; to VICKI) Sounds like your pal's cranked it up a notch. VICKI starts to protest, but thinks better of it.
ALFRED opens the door.  A BANNER HEADLINE stares him in t face:
Industrialist Linked to Drug Smuggling Ring VICKI, who's holding up the afternoon paper for ALFRED's inspection, peeks out glumly from behind the masthead. VICKI
Seen the late edition? ALFRED
I'm afraid so, Miss Vale.  Master Bruce is sequestered in the cave.

On their way to the Batcave, ALFRED and VICKI pass throug library.  They pause in front of the television -- which tuned to a PANEL SHOW, with various experts discussing th issue of the day. ENVIRONMENTALIST (on TV)
Walter Barrett's no saint.  His factories have been dumping poison into the air and water for years.  If he  is mixed up with drugs... PUNDIT (on TV)
That's not the issue.  The issue is, do we entrust our public safety to some...masked vigilante.   Does Batman have a license to kill
ALFRED

(shaking his head) Ah, the public.  Dishearteningly fickle. VICKI follows ALFRED out.  We HOLD on the TV as the CAMER PANS OVER to the third guest on the panel, loudly demandi air time.  He's wearing a RED BERET and a BATMAN SWEATSHI MIKE SEKOWSKY (on TV)
Yo, here's the tip, man.  Drug dealers are scum .  If Batman  did wax these punks...SO WHAT?  They deserved it!  End of discussion.
ALFRED and VICKI arrive; BRUCE gestures for them to keep quiet.  He's hunched over a TAPE RECORDER -- and COMMISSI GORDON'S VOICE is blaring from a nearby speaker... GORDON (O.S.; filter)
Anyone could've written that note.
GORDON's in conference with a number of CITY OFFICIALS -- blissfully unaware that anyone might be eavesdropping. CITY OFFICIAL I
And I suppose anyone could've taken out a boatload of armed thugs.  A dozen men, Jim -- murdered in cold blood -- GORDON
Before we forget, Batman's saved hundreds of lives! CITY OFFICIAL II
He's still a vigilante.  We don't know who he is, where he comes from, why he does it... CITY OFFICIAL I

Street punks are one thing, Jim.  This is Walter Barrett -- a personal friend of mine! As the conversation continues, CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES IN ON COMPUTER TERMINAL in the corner.  We see the tiny TRADEMA embossed on the CPU -- "WAYNE TECHNOLOGIES."
as he LISTENS through his concealed bug. CITY OFFCIAL II
You've gotta bring him in, Jim -- at least for questioning.  It would sure help if we could get that mask off... BRUCE shuts the recorder off.  He turns to face ALFRED an
BRUCE
Ladies and gentlemen...I've been framed.
The BAT-SIGNAL blazing in the night sky.  After a beat, t CAMERA TILTS DOWN to a cluster of EXCITED CITIZENS, who p and holler as the BATMOBILE streaks past.
TWO COPS are parked in an alleyway, watching as the BATMO whizzes past on the street.  The DRIVER pulls out behind the second COP grabs his radio mike... COP
One-delta-niner -- 10-80 on Riverview north-bound at 33rd -- 10-78, repeat 10-78. VOICE ON RADIO (filter)
10-4, one-delta-niner -- that's a 10-37, repeat 10-37.  Backup on the way.
BARRELING TOWARD US on the street.  The SQUAD CAR gains b it.  A SIREN HOWLS; a red-and-blue bubble begins to flash The BATMOBILE makes a HAIRPIN TURN -- and ACCELERATES.

As the BATMOBILE rounds the corner and picks up speed, TW MORE SQUAD CARS scream down the cross street, joining in pursuit.  All at once THICK BLACK SMOKE billows from the of the Batmobile -- ENVELOPING the police cars, BLINDING DRIVERS...

TWO SQUAD CARS parked in a V-formation -- a makeshift roadblock.  ANXIOUS POLICEMEN mill about in front of them They move into position as the BATMOBILE, still trailing smoke, rounds a corner and careens directly toward them..
The FRONT FENDER of the Batmobile detaches and EXTENDS it from the body of the car.  It BENDS in the middle; WING-P flip into place, forming an arrowhead-shaped COW-CATCHER.

A SHRIEKING HORN BLARES.  The COPS see the Batmobile SPEE UP and dive for the sidewalk.  The COW-CATCHER slams into SOUAD CARS, pushes them effortlessly aside, and cruises through the gap. As the PURSUING CARS emerge from the smoke cloud and foll the Batmobile through, we TILT UP to the roof of a nearby building --

-- and realize that the Batmobile's on automatic pilot, because BATMAN's been on the roof all along -- watching t action with some dismay. His relationship with the Gotham PD appears to be on shak ground.  He speaks into his voice-activated REMOTE CONTRO
BATMAN
Evasive. SIRENS HOWL below as he strolls across the rooftop, lost thought.

At this height, the SIRENS are a distant insect drone.  W in the palatial digs of RANDALL SHAW, the construction magnate.  There's obviously money to be made in real-esta development -- because the walls are lined with art, and floor-to-ceiling windows open on the most spectacular vie Gotham. At the moment, SHAW's posing casually in front of his new Brancusi -- which rests on a pedestal near the windows. UNIDENTIFIED WOMAN in a slinky black dress LOOKS ON, her to the camera... WOMAN
It's a fake. SHAW
Hmm.  It cost me a half a million dollars. You're sure? WOMAN

Absolutely.  You see, I...happen to know where the real one is stashed. The WOMAN wanders out of frame as SHAW smiles, impressed. seems peculiarly nonchalant about the whole deal; at the moment, art is not the first thing on his mind.  CAMERA S ON HIM as he pours two glasses of red wine and circles in his mysterious guest. SHAW
I guess you'd know.  I have some "friends" in the art world.  They say that -- for certain hard-to-get items -- you're the one to call. WOMAN (O.S.)
How flattering. SHAW
They say for the right price...you could steal Michelangelo off the Sistine Chapel Wall. WOMAN (O.S.)
Mr. Shaw.  Do you believe everything you hear? SHAW

Oh, I'm not one to judge.  I admire people who take what they want.  I'm just curious how you  do it. SHAW hands her the wine, and for the first time we see he face.  It's SELINA KYLE, perching seductively on the arm the sofa... SELINA

I find that the old methods work best. Setting her wine down, flashing her patented Cheshire-cat smile, SELINA moves in on him -- and they go into a deep, passionate kiss.  Her long red nails dig into his back; S drops his wine glass, which SHATTERS -- splashing red win across the polished parquet floor.

The action's gone horizontal.  SELINA, peeled down to a s lace teddy, is on the bed atop SHAW -- tickling his throa with quick, lapping kisses.  She rolls off suddenly; when tries to sit up, she pushes him back down with a single finger. Sitting on the edge of the bed, she peels off her STOCKIN twisting them around into tight cords.  With a coy smile runs her finger in a circle around SHAW's hairy chest -- then, abruptly, knots one stocking tightly about his wris ties it off on the bedpost. SHAW
Hey, what are you doing -- ? He tries to break her grip.  She BACKHANDS him sharply ac the face. SELINA

You're very inquisitive.  You'll just have to be  disciplined . An EDGY SMILE spreads across his face as she binds his ot hand to the bedpost.  None too quick, he's just caught on all this is part of SELINA's kinky scene.  She crosses qu to the bathroom -- SHAW
You know, I've...I've never really done this kind of thing before. -- and reemerges wearing her CATWOMAN mask...which seems perfectly appropriate in this context. SELINA

I think people should indulge their fantasies.  Don't you? Now that he's all trussed up, she crosses the room and re into an oversized bag.  She withdraws an odd-looking chro BRACE, slips it on over her wrist, and hits a trigger.  S INCH STEEL TALONS snick into place.  SHAW's dopey smile fades... SHAW

Hey, what are those -- what are you -- He lets out an awful, shrill SHRIEK as the camera WHIP PA away from the bed to a Jackson Pollack on the wall nearby SPRAY OF BLOOD spatters across it -- in an aesthetically pleasing way -- and the SHRIEK ends in a LOW GURGLE as we

A SECURITY GUARD is working a crossword at his booth near entrance of the building.  Behind him, a bank of MONITORS various empty hallways throughout the building.  He reach for his coffee and sees a RED LIGHT flashing on a wall pa nearby.

The penthouse is THROBBING with the clangorous sound of a BURGLAR ALARM.  SELINA is standing by an OPEN WALL SAFE - concealed behind a painting, which has been swung away on hinges -- and she's HOLDING HER EARS, wearing a look of complete exasperation:  oh, shit .  The GUARD'S VOICE crackles over a nearby intercom: GUARD (O.S.; filter)

Mr. Shaw?  What's going on up there?  -- Mr. Shaw? Furious with herself, she reaches inside the safe and ext a BLACK RAVEN statuette -- identical to the one she took the docks.  She slams the door shut and swings the pictur back into place.
SIRENS echo in the streets.  SQUAD CARS make sudden turns streak off toward SHAW's building.

Watching the cars from his rooftop vantage, BATMAN raises ANTENNA mounted on his utility belt and cups one hand to head.  An EARPIECE concealed inside his cowl gives him th police frequency: DISPATCHER (O.S.; filter)

-- possible 15 in progress, 188 E. 69th at Gotham Park West.  Move out.  It's Randall Shaw.  Repeat, all units -- BATMAN's eyes widen.  He steps to the ledge and pulls a T METAL CYLINDER from his belt -- immediately recognizable part of BRUCE's hydraulic umbrella-gizmo. But it's no umbrella.  When BATMAN thumbs the switch, his BLACK CAPE begins to SPREAD and RISE -- stiffening, expan -- INFLATING itself into a pair of RIGID BLACK BATWINGS. He steps OFF THE LEDGE, INTO MIDAIR -- SOARING SILENTLY A THE STREET LIKE A HUMAN HANG-GLIDER as the cop cars cruis past far below.

There's an awful BANGING at the front door.  SHAW lies un the bloody sheets, hands folded, staring lifelessly up at ceiling.  SELINA, now dressed in full Catwoman regalia, s a lightweight KNAPSACK over her shoulders.  She picks up nearest chair, RAMS IT through SHAW's plate-glass window, clambers out onto the ledge outside. Ten seconds later the COPS burst in.  They rush to the be -- spot the shattered window, the inert gory mass on the bed -- -- but the  real shock comes when they glance over at the wall. Painted there, in blood...is a big, red, dripping BAT. COP

Forty stories up.  The CATWOMAN, in a surefooted crouch, scurries along the ledge -- SPRINGS at a cornice -- and i lithe motion VAULTS UP onto the ROOF.  She scampers acros rooftops, dropping from one to the next with rope and tac like a mountain climber -- -- until she reaches the building at the end of the block Here she pauses to dig in her knapsack.  She pulls out a retractable HOOK at the end of a rope, swings it around, HEAVES IT at the rooftop across the street...

POLICE pile out of cars and race for the entrance, totall oblivious to the odd scene taking place overhead -- where small, barely-visible figure of a WOMAN, clad entirely in black leather, is doing a TIGHTROPE WALK across the intersection.

The CATWOMAN bounds across snowy rooftops until she decid she's out of danger.  Then, weary and exhilarated, she dr to her knees; bathed in moonlight, she preens, stretches, emits eerie little purrs and hisses of pleasure.  She's j made a kill and her blood is running high, so she's stopp for a moment of Quality Time. She hears an odd crunching noise two roofs over.  Her who body tenses and -- though her head doesn't move -- her ey dart left. A CAPED SHADOW has just touched down at the end of a line The gold BAT-EMBLEM on his chest is visible for the brief of seconds before he steps back into the shadows.  She ac like she hasn't noticed... ...but a little smile flickers across her lips just the s
His eyes widen -- his LIPS PART as he watches her.  If it possible to see absolute consternation behind that mask, seeing it now.

She still doesn't let on that she's seen him.  Instead, s goes to the ledge of the roof and begins to STRUT, like a gymnast on the balance beam -- POSING for him in a little private show -- a strange, self-infatuated, AUTOEROTIC DA ROUTINE for BATMAN's benefit.

His jaw is down around his knees.   Whoa .  He edges forward slightly, as if hypnotically drawn to her... She hears a noise.  Stops.  Makes a big show of looking l and right.  Somehow afraid she'll see him watching, BATMA jumps back into the shadows.  She gathers her things; a s WHITE CARD flutters from her knapsack to the snowy roof, she VANISHES over the edge. Snapping back to reality, he bolts across the roof just i time to see --

She's rapidly working her way down the side of the buildi flipping down from one fire escape to tile next -- a mast gymnast.  Three stories up, she lands on a railing, then -- LAUNCHING HERSELF out over the street, making a perfec landing on the roof of a passing BUS.
BATMAN turns -- and his eyes fall on the WHITE CARD.  He kneels to pick it up; a brief three-word MESSAGE is scraw upon it...

He goes goggle-eyed with astonishment.  He rushes back to edge of the roof and sees the BUS just turning toward the entrance to Gotham Park.  He's reaching for his grappling figuring to follow, when a FLOODLIGHT catches him full in face.
Down below, the cops are sweeping their beams across the rooftops.  Two of them catch a quick glimpse of BATMAN ju he ducks back behind the cornice, out of view. COP

Hey.  You see what I saw...? This sends the astounded COPS rushing to their radios.  R on cue, COMMISSIONER GORDON's car pulls up.  LT. BULLOCK, who's already on the scene, fills him in as he climbs out BULLOCK
It's Randall Shaw.  Torn to ribbons.  -- We just made Batman up on the roof. GORDON
Oh God.

The BUS rumbles deeper into the snowy park.  A BLACK SILHOUETTE springs off the roof into the trees, disappear among the branches... We TRACK WITH the bus as it moves through the park, arriv finally at:

The little colony of HOMELESS PEOPLE in their cardboard s and lean-tos, still occupying the future site of the Park Towers.  MARCHERS and PICKETERS are continuing their prot nearby, and some charitable organization's set up a makes soup kitchen on folding tables -- hot coffee and sandwich VICKI's on the periphery of the camp, camera in hand.  Sh trying to persuade a HOMELESS MAN to let his picture be t VICKI
Please, just one.  It's important for people to see what's happening. HOMELESS MAN

They don't want to see us, lady.  They just want us  gone -- out of sight, and out of mind. (mumbling as he wanders off) Get worse before it gets better.  It always does. VICKI TURNS.  In the distance, the PICKETERS are shriekin wailing.  A VAN's just pulled up to the edge of the park, a dozen HARDHATS are elbowing their way through the crowd All at once they're swarming through shantytown with TIRE IRONS and BASEBALL BATS, overturning the sandwich tables, RIPPING DOWN the shabby tents and lean-tos. Some of the HOMELESS PEOPLE run.  Those who resist meet w swift and sudden violence.  A MARCHER jumps a hardhat, an gets a baseball bat in the gut for his trouble. VICKI waits for the police sirens, but  they don't come .  She backs off toward the trees, she begins SNAPPING PHOTOS FRANTICALLY, capturing the carnage on film. A HARDHAT is dismantling a lean-to with his tire iron -- sending the terrified family inside scurrying off into th snow -- when he glances up and sees VICKI taking his pict He points her out to a colleague... ...and suddenly the two of them are RUSHING TOWARD HER wi pure cold malice in their eyes.  VICKI turns to run, but slow going in the snow.  She SLIPS and FALLS; her attacke are almost upon her... ...when a SHADOWY FIGURE DIVES OUT OF THE TREES and TACKL one of the HARDHATS.  The FIGURE lands a powerhouse blow the fallen HARDHATs jaw, knocking him out cold. The second HARDHAT turns and lifts his TIRE IRON.  But th FIGURE, with surprising agility, is already rolling out o way.  As he rolls, he grabs the first guy's HARDHAT off h head and brings it up in front of him -- blocking the blo from the second guy's tire iron. In the same motion, he plants a FOOT in the second HARDHA belly and sends him REELING BACKWARD, HARDHAT II drops th tire iron, and the FIGURE snatches it out of midair as he to his feet.  He moves in on the second HARDHAT, BRANDISH the iron -- -- and while HARDHAT II is staring at it, the FIGURE HIGH KICKS HIM in the face.  HOP; KICK.  HOP; KICK.  The FIGUR nailed him three times squarely on the jaw before he can the ground. The FIGURE turns toward VICKI.  Her eyes go wide with astonishment. It's a KID, thirteen or fourteen at the outside, sunken-e grimy-looking, in a torn-and-tattered RAINCOAT.  She star him for the briefest of instants before he rushes off to aid of his fellow homeless... She can't believe what she's seeing.  The KID wades smack the midst of the remaining HARDHATS, and  kicks ass

spinning, pirouetting, kicking, clawing in a furious disp of pure athleticism.  It seems like he's everywhere at on There's only one other guy in Gotham City who can handle himself like this... Rallying behind him, the MARCHERS and HOMELESS PEOPLE sna bats and tire irons from the fallen HARDHATS -- and the t turns.  The invasion is being repelled.  Faced with renew resistance, the few HARDHATS still left standing TURN TAI race off to their VAN. Triumph in shantytown.  The MARCHERS and HOMELESS cluster together to lick their wounds -- and the KID, satisfied t everything is under control, turns and sprints off toward trees. But one prostrate HARDHAT is only playing dead.  As the K runs past, the HARDHAT extends a TIRE IRON into his path TRIPPING HIM, sending him sprawling in the snow.  The KID throws up his hands as the HARDHAT prepares to smash down him... CLANG.  The HARDHAT drops his tire iron and topples over, BOARDLIKE.  The KID looks up and sees VICKI standing ther with a baseball bat. He gives her a quick nod of acknowledgement as he gets to feet -- thanks for returning the favor.  He's about to li out again when -- VICKI
!  Don't be afraid.  I wanted to  thank you.  I -- KID
(cautiously) Twenty. VICKI
What? KID

Twenty bucks. VICKI's mildly taken aback, but she reaches for her purse the same.  She's barely gotten her wallet open when the K snatches the bill out of her hands.  They stare at each o for a long moment -- VICKI
...Who  are you? KID

Dick. -- and then he's bounding off like a shot.  VAULTING up i tree and vanishing amid the snowy branches.  VICKI starts follow, but there's no way she can keep up.  Instead she into her CAMERA BAG...

Using the long lens, she tracks the KID's progress throug treetops.  She can't actually see him, but occasional chu of SNOW and ICE are falling to the ground as he jumps fro limb to limb... For a moment it seems like she's lost him.  As she sweeps lens back and forth, scanning the trees, she catches sigh an EQUESTRIAN STATUE in the distance.  She ups the magnification so she can see the plaque on the pedestal. stone figure on the horse is Union war hero GEN. OLIVER W -- BRUCE's great-grandfather. As luck would have it, the KID drops to earth not ten fee from the statue -- VICKI's got him in her sights again. looks around cautiously to make sure no one's following, races toward a STONE BRIDGE which arches between two smal hillocks, over a frozen creek. There's a DRAINAGE TUNNEL, four or five feet in diameter, mounted in the bridge abutment, the KID pries off a wire and clambers inside, then pulls the grate back into place behind him.  Home sweet home.

as she lowers the lens.  Her face is full of conflicting emotions.  She'd love to corner this boy vigilante and fi out what his story is.  But on the other hand -- even the homeless are entitled to their privacy...

A CANARY sings in its cage as a BLACK CAT watches transfi from a nearby chair.  The cat arches its back -- waits -- SPRINGS AT THE CAGE, BATTING at it in midair.  The canary SHRIEKS; the cat YOWLS; a WOMAN snatches it up off the fl cradles it in her arms... WOMAN'S VOICE

Now Hecate.  You don't want that scrawny little bird -- It's SELINA, looking ripe and slinky in a sheer black ensemble.  At the desk behind her is the PENGUIN, in his customary cutaway and waist-coat, polishing his new RAVEN bares his teeth: PENGUIN
Do you want me to wring that creature's neck? SELINA
You try it, I'll do the same to you. (as he grumbles; bemused) I saw him, you know. PENGUIN
Saw who? SELINA
Batman.  He was  dreamy . She strokes the cat, in a reverie.  The PENGUIN drops his polishing cloth, startled. PENGUIN
Dreamy ?!?  Are you insane!?  My God -- (sputtering wildly) Are you sure it was  him ?  What did he do? SELINA

He stood on a roof and watched me.  He didn't realize I'd seen him.  I don't think he knew quite what to make of me. (smiling) But he was definitely interested. This sends the PENGUIN into a frantic round of pacing.  ( waddling.) PENGUIN
This scheme of yours is backfiring.  We don't need  him on our tails.  Do you know how much  money is at stake here? SELINA
Money isn't everything. (casually) What's the point if we can't enjoy ourselves? She chuckles to herself.  He stares at her in disbelief - SQUAWKS.
The big SIGN over Gotham Square tells us there are only 9 shopping days left until Christmas.  Down below, BRUCE is walking VICKI to work. VICKI
Six-on-one, and he took 'em all out...then vanished into a drainage pipe -- right next to the statue of General Wayne. BRUCE
My illustrious great-grandfather.  Think it's the same kid we heard about? VICKI
Must be.  He reminded me of  you . BRUCE chuckles. They pass a NEWSSTAND just outside the  Globe building, pausing to stare at the headlines -- which SCRE

Batman Suspect in Slaying of Millionaire Developer Commissioner Gordon Refuses Comment The accompanying photo is a full-color spread of the BLOO RED BAT painted on SHAW's wall.  BRUCE scowls at VICKI: BRUCE

-- You  work for this rag? (snatching up a paper) Your boss is calling for Gordon's resignation -- unless he brings Batman in for questioning... VICKI nudges BRUCE and points at a STOREFRONT across the street.

The owner is in the store window, hastily removing all of Batman merchandise and setting up new displays devoted to TEENAGE MUTANT NINJA TURTLES and THE SIMPSONS.  A MOTHER her squirming TODDLER past the entrance -- the kid smells heavy markdowns on Bat-shit, but Mom clearly doesn't approve...
looking on in dismay.  BRUCE crumples the paper in outrag BRUCE
I need a good PR man. NEWS VENDOR
Hey, pal -- you buyin' or borrowin'? With a sullen look, BRUCE tosses the paper back on the ra VICKI pulls him off toward the entrance of the  Globe . VICKI
That's what happens when you go after the rich and powerful. BRUCE

Hey, it  wasn't me , remember?  I  am rich and powerful -- As he's talking, BRUCE glances back at the newsstand.  He an AD FLYER tacked up on one side -- "LOOKING FOR LOVE? it in the GOTHAM GLOBE PERSONALS." Looking for Love .  Eyes widening, he digs in his pocket for a quarter and races back to the newsstand.  VICKI keeps walking... VICKI

Maybe it's almost...good.  In a weird way. I mean, Shaw, and Barrett -- if people like that were really  scared , maybe they'd -- She suddenly realizes she's talking to herself.  She turn around and sees BRUCE back at the newsstand, hurriedly unfolding a copy of the  Globe .  She marches back and tugs at his sleeve. VICKI (cont.)
Hey, I'm late for work.  You can read that later. BRUCE
Quiet.  I'm looking for a personal ad. Her face screws up in confusion as BRUCE frantically scan page. BRUCE (cont.)
"Tall, Dark And Handsome -- You saw me on  the roof 12/16.  I was in black; you were too." VICKI
Is this some kind of bad joke? BRUCE
It's her.  That  cat woman, or whatever she is. (reading aloud) "I jumped a bus into Gotham Park hoping you'd follow, but you were too shy..." VICKI
What does she want -- a date? BRUCE

She's trying to contact me.  Says she's gonna leave me another ad... The two of them exchange a look of utter perplexity.  BRU mind is racing; he seems bizarrely  aroused -- in a way that makes VICKI just a trifle nervous...
VICKI arrives at her desk and sets her portfolio down.  S spots a message in the "in" file.  She takes one look at and her eyes go wide with RAGE.  She storms out in a fury
Barging past a phalanx of SECRETARIES, VICKI bursts into inner office of HARRISON J. PROVOST, publisher of the  Globe . He's just opening his mail.  He heaves a weary sigh as VI BARKS at him: VICKI

head_text.subj: WHY DID YOU KILL MY STORY

text: PROVOST
Close the door. (waiting for her to calm down) Your story isn't  news .  With Shaw dead -- VICKI
But the project's still going ahead!  If attacking homeless people in the park isn't news, I'd like to know what is -- PROVOST

There's a  psycho out there in a mask and cape -- killing off Gotham's most prominent citizens!   That's news. (beat) I've known Randall Shaw all my life.  His family is in mourning.  And it just so happens I don't believe in slandering the dead . VICKI FUMES.  She turns and stares PROVOST straight in th eye. VICKI
Mr. Provost -- how much money do you have tied up in the Park Tower project? PROVOST

Vicki...I'm going to forget you made that remark.  For the sake of your job, I suggest you do the same. VICKI stalks of -- and PROVOST goes back to his mail.  He finds an envelope addressed in a shaky, psychotic scrawl, the word "CONFIDENTIAL" underlined three times in ink.  H tears it open -- -- and HIS FACE TURNS PALE as he stares down at the conte a small business-sized card, signed with a BAT-EMBLEM...

head_text.subj: THOSE WHO FEED ON THE SOUL OF GOTHAM

text: WALTER BARRETT and his ATTORNEY emerge onto the front ste the courthouse.  BARRETT is instantly mobbed by REPORTERS REPORTER I
Mr. Barrett!  Any comment on the arraignment? REPORTER II
Is it true bail was set at two million dollars? ATTORNEY

Stand back!  My client has nothing to say at this time! The ATTORNEY clears a path for BARRETT, who climbs into a waiting CAR, shielding his face.  REPORTERS cluster aroun it... As the car pulls out into traffic, we see a flock of PIGE taking wing from their perches on the statues outside the of Justice.
PIGEONS fill the frame, swooping down toward the CAR, whi idling at a traffic light far below.
The liveried DRIVER drums his fingers as he waits for the light to change.  BARRETT's in the back, speaking into hi cellular phone. BARRETT

It's time we called an emergency meeting of the Raven Society.  Get back to me... Looking troubled, he hangs up.  A fat white glob of PIGEO SHIT splatters across the windshield.  Seconds later -- another SPLAT. BARRETT (cont.)
Damn pigeons. DRIVER

Just washed it, too. The DRIVER reaches for the wiper switch.  They hear a tin DINK as a SOLID PELLET bounces off the windshield. BARRETT and the DRIVER exchange a mystified look.  A smal blinking CAPSULE has just lodged in the wiper-blade assembly...
Just as the light changes, the CAR EXPLODES into a millio fragments -- leaving a BLACKENED CRATER in the middle of intersection.
TIGHT ON A VIDEO MONITOR -- showing FIRE TRUCKS in the intersection we've just left, hosing down the wreckage of BARRETT's car.  BRUCE is watching intently when ALFRED ap behind him. ALFRED
The Fluegelheim called again, sir.  They want to know if you'll be attending the opening of the new Egyptian exhibit. BRUCE, still engrossed in his news broadcast, waves ALFRE off. BRUCE
Cancel . ANCHORWOMAN (on TV)

-- and, citing new evidence in the so- called string of "millionaire murders," Police Commissioner J.T. Gordon today swore out a warrant for the arrest of Batman. (beat) We go now live to Mike Sekowsky, spokesperson, Order of the Bat. SEKOWSKY
Jeez!  Talk about  gratitude
At the sight of SEKOWSKY's face, BRUCE kills the sound in disgust.  ALFRED looks on helplessly as he paces the floo the Batcave. BRUCE

Well, Alfred, it's official.  I'm a wanted man. (beat) "New evidence"...I've gotta find that woman.  Did you check the personals? As ALFRED shakes his head no, a BUZZER sounds.  They've g visitor.  BRUCE hits a switch on a monitor, and sees COMMISSIONER GORDON'S CAR sitting outside the wrought-iro gates of Wayne Manor. He throws a nervous look at ALFRED.  ALFRED speaks into a microphone: ALFRED
Who's there? GORDON
Jim Gordon, Alfred.  I've got to see Bruce. A spooky development.  Does GORDON suspect?  After a mome hesitation, BRUCE nods to ALFRED -- let him in. ALFRED
Mr. Wayne will see you, sir.
A curious BRUCE ushers GORDON into the library, gestures toward the liquor cabinet.  The Commissioner nods his hea He's fidgety, ill at ease -- he obviously doesn't want to here. GORDON
Sorry to bother you.  Bruce -- I'll get right down to it.  You knew Shaw and Barrett -- BRUCE
I saw them occasionally.  We all sat on the board of the Fluegelheim... GORDON
Did you have any...dealings with them, or -- BRUCE
No.  I never liked the way they did business. GORDON

The thing is, Bruce, you're all lumped together in the public mind -- the Five Families of Gotham, that sort of thing -- and, uh... (taking a card from his pocket) Harrison Provost got this in the mail. BRUCE examines the card, -- "THOSE WHO FEED," etc.  He st at GORDON in mock-concern, playing it close to the vest.. BRUCE
Then Batman  is behind all this. GORDON
Batman or a damned good imitation. BRUCE
Well.  He's changed tactics, hasn't he. GORDON

(shrugging; at a loss) Shaw, with his high-rises -- Barrett, a druglord, major polluter -- they weren't exactly model citizens.  Who knows, it could be some crazy social-conscience kind of thing. BRUCE
You mean he's going after...the root of the problem. GORDON shakes his head and gets up to go.  BRUCE hands hi card. GORDON
